column1: Will voter turnout for the 2019 European Parliament elections set a record low?
column6: ['Society', 'Elections and Referenda', 'Non-US Politics']
column11: Pivotal elections to the European Parliament are scheduled for May 2019, and Brussels is working to increase turnout -- in 2014 the final figure was a record-low 42.61% (Bloomberg, Politico). This question will be suspended the day before the election and closed based on the turnout figures available on the European Parliament website at the time of the first sitting of the newly-elected Parliament; for more information on turnout in past elections see The European Parliament and select "Turnout," "By year," and "European Union." Confused? Check our FAQ or ask us for help.

column6: On balance, well conscious about the 50:50 tendency of this question overall and the cognitive dissonance to my prediction, I have gone through the material, once again, and I still cannot fit into my head why there would be a new record low. Does not fit the bill, I cannot get my head around it, but my prediction is too obvious to my mind (and I am more pro EU than not, fitting, huh?), hence the pounding in my head ;-) ...and I know the tricks our minds play on ourselves, regardless of ourselves. Well, it seems that I, at the end of the day, like to take calculated risks! And my body does not.

Adjusting: I strengthen my prediction that the voter turnout in the election of EU Parliament will not set a record low. One reason is time period as it is only a couple days left until election, the likelihood that something highly unexpected will happen and impact the voters’ participation is very limited. Second, as UK is one of the biggest countries in the EU, its people participation has a huge impact towards the final turnout of the EU election. Also, as it was mentioned in the previous analysis, British usually have one of the lowest turnout in the EU election. Even though, in opposite when I assumed, Britain will take part in EU elections, it does not increase the likelihood of lowest turnout. Responding to many British people “mood”, the EU election this year has a bigger weight than any previous ones. Lots of people the participation in it see as one more EU referendum and a chance to show for, firstly, Britain politicians that they want to stay in EU. Based on previous arguments, I assume that the voters’ turnout will not be the lowest.
Four out of ten French people indifferent to EU elections https://www.euractiv.com/section/eu-elections-2019/news/four-out-of-ten-french-people-are-indifferent-to-the-2019-eu-elections/
There’s quite frankly too much local & regional variation to account for.

The Finnish preliminary EP election period ended today. 21% of the voters voted early. 5 years ago the number was 17.4%. As the Finnish saying goes, "one swallow will not make it summer", but confirming my "no"-bet. "So far so good", answered the man who'd jumped from a skyscraper and half-way hurling towards the ground to the question "How's it going?" :-) ... I'll get my coat...

Tomorrow is the moment of truth. I am dropping my previous prediction of 17% to 6%. With Brexit and more populists potentially coming to the polls, I wanted to modify my prediction. Still, my prediction could be very inaccurate.

Update: In my initial forecast, I speculated that Denmark would be one of the countries to hold the EP election in conjunction other elections, thus increasing voter participation. However, this will not be the case as Denmark's general election will be held on July 5th. It was the hypothesis that joined elections would boost a slumping voter turnout, as it would bring voters who are otherwise not engaged with the EU to the voting booths. Hence, Denmark's participation rate will likely not increase as predicted. In my initial prediction, I also assumed that the UK would not be partaking in the EU elections, but it is shaping up to be one more British EP election. Normally, voter turnout in the UK has been lover than the average European participation, but it has been suggested that the current Brexit chaos will bring out voters from both the ‘remain’ and the ‘hard-Brexit’ side will participate in increased numbers to showcase their respective feelings about UK’s continued involvement with the EU. Potentially, if voter turnout increases significantly, the UK participation could add positively to the overall voter participation. Overall, surveys have shown that 48% of European citizens believe that 'their voice counts in the EU', which is an increase from past years. Yet, only 43 % of eligible voters respond that they are certain that they will vote. This is not an immediate increase from past years’ participation, however, the increased commitment to EU could indicate that participation will not continue its free-fall. This is supported by the reports that an increasing amount of European citizens report that they consider their European identity as important as their national identity. On the basis of the above, I still believe that the elections will not set a record low, however, I keep probability at 15%.

I assume that there’s a 15% chance of voter turnout for the 2019 European parliament elections to set a record low. Below are the major reasons explaining my point of view:
Trend is strong, UK seems more likely to depress turnout than increase it.
Voter Skepticism after Brexit

Well, the UK are in for the election, which will definitely: (1) crash turnout if they decide they don't care and stay home in their millions, (b) skyrocket turnout if they decide to vote for every anti-EU candidate who ever drew breath to teach somebody a lesson about something or other, or (c) lodge turnout somewhere in between because Who Knows Why.

Update: With UK participation in the EP elections the chances of a low voter turnout is going up. Citizens in the UK are tired of the Brexit negotiations and the meaningless choosing of a candidate, that will stay in Brussels only for a couple of month (as the deal is right now), will arouse voters to get out and vote. The campaigning will also mere less intense than otherwise.

Although the EU is making efforts to fight voter apathy and encourage younger voters to come out to the ballots, the factors that have been in play for the past decades haven’t changed. Voters have a greater interest in their national elections than in EU parliamentary elections because they do not agree on the direction the EU is taking. Steps have been made to increase voter turnout through get-out-to-vote campaigns sponsored by two major EU parties while some nations have made voting compulsory; however, these efforts have not made a major impact on the number of voters who participate. Therefore, it is likely that voter turnout for the 2019 European Parliament will remain low.
This forecast is just an initial estimate. I looked at data from past European Union parliamentary elections, and found the average voting rate was 52.14%, so I’m using that as a base rate.

Update: the UK's participation in the election is cause for slightly adjusting the forecast. They have historically had below-average voter turn-outs, and this was a consideration in earlier forecasts which had expected that the UK would not participate in the EU Parliamentary election. However, given the current political climate in the UK and public discontent with Brexit, it does seem probable that more will head to the polling booths to have their say (for one last time). That being said, and the reason for the slight increase in this forecast, these is also the possibility that Brits refrain from voting, knowing that Brexit is looming, which could bring down the EU-wide average.

Update: I have decided to decrease my percentage to 15% since the last forecast was made. Simply put, this decrease is due to the fact that I believe the European people this election have more to vote for compared to previous elections. Seeing as several of the EU state have parties running on the basis of leaving the EU following the sparks made by Brexit, the rise of populist parties all across the continent, local and international debates about topics like climate change and immigration, it is in my opinion expected that people will have a stronger incentive to take to the polls. With the added campaigns posted by the EU, I find it likely that voter turnout will not be at an all time low.

The European Parliament brings tension to some Europeans. Many feel as if their voice is not valued in the EU. There is some truth to it, though. There is a democratic deficit, which hurts democracy in Europe. This might actually lead people to vote more. However, I feel as if the EU will not see a high voter turnout due to the problems surrounding it and the ineffectiveness that people feel they have.
There is increased lack of interest in France in Feb 35% not interested, March 36% now 42% not interested.

Forecast Update #5:

Dropping a few points based on polling showing significantly increased voter engagement over 5 years ago according to Eurobarometer. It is still low compared to national elections but compared to 2014 it's an improvement.

The UK Labour Party yesterday confirmed its Brexit position. This will surely affect turnout by Labour Party Members and supporters for the EU Parliamentary Elections. The Labour position is that it will support a Public Vote on a Conservative version of Brexit, but will not support a Public Vote on a Labour version of Brexit. I don't know if Labour voters will have spotted the logic of this. A Conservative version of Brexit could only pass the UK Parliament if the Conservative Government was able to get a majority of MPs to back it. If a majority of MPs had just voted thru a Conservative version of Brexit those same MPs would hardly be likely to then vote to first hold a Public Vote on the deal that they have voted for. If the Government had got its Brexit Bill thru Parliament the UK would leave the EU, which means it would be too late to hold a Public Vote on it. If somehow the Conservative Government could be persuaded to support a Labour version of Brexit and there was a majority of MPs who would vote for it, then according to the Labour Policy there would be no need to have a Public Vote. So a "Conservative" version of Brexit would be opposed by Labour, who would demand a Public Vote. If there were enough MPs to vote it thru it would not matter what Labour demanded because it would be passed anyway without a Public Vote. If there were not enough MPs to to pass the Consevative version of Brexit it would not happen and so no Public Vote is needed. So in short the Labour policy is pointless because Labour would never have the number of MPs to demand a Public Vote on a Conservative version of Brexit that was able to pass in parliament. As 2/3 of Labour voters support Remain, and up to 80% of Labour members are in favour of a Public Vote on any Brexit deal, the cunning plan by the Labour leadership to try and appeal to Leavers by saying they would like to push thru a Labour version of Brexit, and to appeal to Remainers by saying that it might be possible to avoid Brexit by having a Public Vote on a Conservative Brexit, does not really work. Many of Labour Leave voters might have been happy with the Conservative Brexit, which Labour is ruling out. And most of the Labour Remain voters will be upset because Labour is ruling out stopping Brexit. So its clear that few Labour voters would get what they want, so why would they bother to vote for Labour candidates for the EU Parliamentory Elections? Their logical choice is to vote for a party that clearly supports Brexit or a party that clearly supports Remain or to refrain from voting at all.

Admittedly, my view is from across the pond, but it seems the expense of bureaucracy outweighs the benefits. Evem Germany is economically slowing. I do not belive they view the Parliament as a critical problem-solving force. It simply does not matter as much as many had hoped.

I am having a rethink on this. The French turnout could well be a record low there, and the UK is set to participate but amidst a climate of apathy. The Brexit party will presumably hover up all the most enthusiastic brexiteers, but the Independent Group/Change UK/CUK/Tiggers (I am not making this up, all names that the party is running under, and you did read *CUK* right) mean that the remainers in the UK have a split choice between the Lib Dems + CUK and may feel like not bothering to show up, as I suspect the majority of British people will feel. Labours position is unclear so if people are voting for them they will manly be doing so because they have always voted Labour.

Making this forecast comes down to weighing a continued trend of voter apathy and a general trend of lessened voter engagement across the world versus the chance that a spike in civic engagement leads to a rally for voter turnout. This election will be the first EP vote since the Brexit referendum, and engagement with the Union has become a more prominently featured topic in both local governance and the news media. Initially while trying to answer this question, I was tempted to pull data from local elections, such as those in Italy and France, that indicate that despite a rise in more populist candidates voter engagement has continued to slide. However, these elections have a much different focus than MEP elections and the interests in one do not necessarily translate over to another. Further, as a general trend the decline in voter turnout itself has declined in more recent elections: That is to say the margin by which elections have less turnout than the prior EP election is shrinking. With these combined factors, it appears highly likely that if any year would be the year for an upset, it would be 2019. http://www.europarl.europa.eu/about-parliament/en/in-the-past/previous-elections https://www.idea.int/data-tools/world-view/40?st=eup#rep https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-02-25/italy-voters-stay-home-as-turnout-on-pace-for-lowest-since-wwii https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/french-election-turnout-emmanuel-macron-parliament-france-victory-fn-marine-le-pen-national-front-a7785366.html

Their projection for the 2014-2019 trend seems to be in line with the previous elections' turnout (a 0.01% increase...). This graph reconfirms my already mentioned opinion: next month's EP elections will substantially stand in line with 2014 elections' turnout. The record low could be a matter of fractions... Update: - The Uk will participate to the elections, because May has asked for an extension of the article 50 till 30th of June. I think that this event could be interpreted in two opposite ways. On one side, would be likely for the Britain people who voted for the “leave” to practice abstentionism, in order to reiterate their position. This would cause a drop in Uk participation rate, influencing the whole European rate. On the other side, the people that voted for the “stay” will participate to the elections, included all the citizens that in the past might not show such an active participation to European election, increasing the rate. However, I believe the first factor is more influent than the second one, so I think it will drop the Uk EU elections participation rate (or, in the best case, keep it equal to the 2014 one), not increasing it. - In some European countries the parties that during the electoral campaign were claiming to get out from Europe or from Euro now are reconsidering their idea, because reality is always more complicated and implies more (bad) consequences than any populist slogan. Italian example: suddenly, the Lega leader Salvini proclaims that he wants to change the EU from the inside, not destroying it anymore. His declaration make me think that a lot of Italian will prefer to follow their ”””captain””” and vote for him also in the European campaign instead of not voting at all. --> this is why I’m going to change my prediction of only 5%

New major factor/hypothesis: though EU voter turnout is clearly in a secular decline (Western civ peak ~1800 AD - 2100 AD end), the rate of decline is mediated by currency strength. When USD is strong and others weak, like in the 1990s, European voters unplugged in droves. When USD is weak and others/Euro strong, like in the 2000s, the decline in Euro voting slowed significantly.

Forecast Update #2:

Since the creation of the European Parliament, the elections turnout data have continued to decrease. The average percentage of participation had reached its peak (61,99%) in 1979, going down in 1984 (58,98), 1989 (58,41%), 1994 (56,67%) until the huge breakdown in 1999 at 49,51%. In 2004 it reached 45,57% and 42,97% in 2009. In the last 2014 elections the result have been the worst, with an attendance of only 42,61%, but very similar to the 2009 results which doesn’t make me forecast a huger declining. https://www.wired.it/attualita/politica/2014/05/23/elezioni-europee-affluenza/ http://www.europarl.europa.eu/elections2014-results/en/election-results-2014.html The lower and lower turnout level could be due to a lack of efficiency and action power perceived by the populations, especially after/during episodes like the economic crisis in 2008 and the refugee crisis. In my view, a huge role is played by the populist anti-European parties that have raised in the last decade in Europe, spread everywhere and founded consensus at the national elections. Those parties have often depicted EU as an enemy that would cared more of bureaucracy and elites than to common lay people, spreading angriness, dissatisfaction and disappointment. Moreover, the recent Brexit referendum and the rise to power of similar movements in other big countries (Trump in USA, Bolsonaro in Brasil), have somehow legitimised those positions. However, after having hit bottom in 2009 and 2014, I think that this year turnout wouldn’t reach the historical minimums. Even the EU does not good well yet, currently there aren’t emergency situation such as in 2009 or 2014. What I forecast instead is a massive flow of votes for anti-European parties: instead of not voting at all, the populations would prefer to vote them aiming to change EU from the inside and asking their politicians to “take back national sovereignty”, even stopping the process of integration (which already had a setback after Lisbon treaty in 2009, with no more structural treaties). “While there are significant divides between them on substance, anti-European parties could align with one another tactically in support of a range of ideas: from abolishing sanctions on Russia to blocking the EU’s foreign trade agenda, to pulling the drawbridge up against migration. This would put at risk Europe’s capacity to defend its citizens from external threats at exactly the time when, given global turmoil, it needs to show more resolve, cooperation, and global leadership.” https://www.ecfr.eu/specials/scorecard/the_2019_European_election On the other side, the pro-Europe citizens would feel the urgency of contrasting the rise of euro-sceptics, going to vote for the opposition. Talking about the Brexit issue, there is evidence of the complexity of getting out from EU without suffering bad consequences and of the fact that EU has un upper hand on the topic. This discourage the idea of leaving the Union and empower EU credibility. Additionally, a lot of countries are going to vote for National elections at the same time of European ones, pushing citizens to vote for both. Finally, EU is doing a massive campaign to teach the youngest electors the importance of European policies, using modern path as youtube, social media, bloggers support. These actions will likely increase the number of voters in elections. Therefore, I predict a low level of participation but not the lowest.

changed the previous forecast to account for increased perceived increased campaigning. The fact that several European countries have chosen to combine National elections with the EP elections could also work in boosting the voter turnout. Simultaneously it could redce the effectiveness of campaigning if the domestic elections take away focus from the EP elections.

The forecast at hand estimates a 10% likelihood for a new record low in the voting turnout for the EP to realize. It is in fact true, that the EP elections voter turnouts experienced a constant downwards trend. However, it has to be noted that compared to the 2009 elections, the voter turnout in 2014 were only 0.36% lower (http://www.europarl.europa.eu/elections2014-results/de/turnout.html). This difference is rather small and considered too small for this forecast to anticipate a further decrease based upon that, in particular given the fact that the long-term downwards trend (almost 20% between 1979 and 2014) got promoted (among other factors) strongly by the expansion of the EU toward the east where voter turnout has been traditionally lower than in the western countries (https://www.kas.de/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=d3b13d4c-81ad-5926-f2eb-d41cbc81f95b&groupId=252038 and https://blog.datawrapper.de/weekly-chart-turnout/). Since there was no further enlargement since the last elections this factor can be excluded.
Thought I'd submit an initial, speculative forecast before further researching the issue. I can imagine the following socio-political shifts influencing voter turnout:

1. The turnout of the last EU election in 2014 was 0.64% lower than in 2009. The difference is not big enough to jump into conclusions about declining turnout. 2. Even though it is visible that there has been a clear decline in the turnout since 1979, one of the explanations could be the enlargement of the EU and the new members who, regarding of a few exceptions, are tend to participate less actively in the EU elections. 3. In case of an extension of Article 50, the UK still has a right to hold an election. However, it is very unlikely that the UK would decide to use it. Therefore, taking into account that the UK's turnout is always below the EU average, it could also increase the overall percentage of participation. 4. Regardless of many discussions and doubts about what will happen with the EU after the Brexit, now it is fear to say that the EU is seen as the winner in this situation. It is hard to tell how it impacts public opinion and participation in the EU elections but I am quite confident to say that EU image looks quite well taking into consideration Brexit, as well as managed migrant crisis.
While there has been a steady decline in voter turnout since 1979, there are a number of factors to forecast this trend will be broken in the upcoming elections:

I claim that there is a 20% chance of record low turnout due to the unbroken downward trend in turnout. However, I think that this election will likely be the one to break the tread. This is for three reasons, there has been a lot of attention on this issue and the democratic legitimacy of the EU. Therefore, I believe that the European Parliament will be working a lot more than in years previous, to increase turnout. Secondly, the trend seems to have slowed from 2009 to 2014 election. Thirdly, since the last European Parliament elections, there has been a lot of attention on the Eu and its importance due to Brexit. Many in Europe, believe the EU to be a benefit and are grateful that they are not going through an exit. Therefore, they feel more sympathetic towards the EU, increasing the likelihood that they'll vote. Moreover, on the other side, Brexit will energize those citizens who do want to exit the EU. Making it more likely that they'll increase their turnout and campaigns.

Even though it could be assumed that voter turnout will be at a record-low, since historically this has been the development so far, I do not believe this will be the case. Indeed, it has been a development also in national elections that voter turnout falls. I believe, however, that the voter turnout in the EU elections will be higher in the 2019 elections due to the following reasons: > usually first time voters abstain more from voting than older voters, according to the platform 'European Youth Ideas' (https://www.politico.eu/interactive/european-elections-most-important-issues-facing-the-eu/). Recently though the EU has taken a great step in promoting the EU and getting awareness with the younger generation. Programs such as the 'thistimeimvoting.eu' campaign are very visible on online platforms, or the hashtag #EUandME has been introduced, creating more awareness among the 'Social-media generation'. Also for the elections now, the EU is taking an effort, e.g. recruiting popular bloggers to promote the EU elections. Hence, it can be assumed that voter turnout for the younger generation could be proportionally higher than the last couple of years.

Adding the UK to the elections, considering chances May's plan is rejected first (85%), and no-deal motion is also rejected right after (90%). Then, UK voters reaction to Brexit delay (1 minus 40%) to 1 minus 40% chance other countries react to Brexit by going to vote.

Despite what the majority of the surveys show, I believe there is a low chance that voters turnout for the 2019 European Parliament elections set a record low. Actually not because, as Politico notes, the European Parliament and European Commission are planning to spend more than €30 million on "get out the vote" advertising and support (which is likely to have only a little impact on the willingness of European citizens to vote). Rather, a number of considerations led me to this conclusion:

According to Politico, "the EU will have difficulty getting more people out to vote next year than they have in the past", as "only half of the EU population has an interest in the Parliament elections". Having 42% of all voters showing up, thus, means that 84% of the people interested in the election will actually vote, which would be highly optimistic. While it is true that some issues, such as climate change and (above all) managing migrants flows motivate people to vote, it is also true that policies on such issues are still mostly implemented according to national legislation, and that the EU has been doing little, if anything, to help solving them. This is precisely what leads to feelings of high skepticism and mistrust towards EU institutions.

Seeing as the last two elections have been somewhat stable, 42.75% in 2009 and 42.61% in 2014 (https://www.politico.eu/interactive/voters-turnout-in-the-european-elections/), one can assume that this years result will follow the same path. With that being said, the European Parliament has for this election put in extra effort to make sure that the voting turnout does not set a record low, with their campaign called 'This Time I'm Voting' (https://www.thistimeimvoting.eu/), providing EU citizens with extensive information about how and where to vote, as well as information about where to vote in the respective countries. This leads me to believe that the voting turnout will stay at around the same number, but that the likelihood is not as high as if the European Parliament had not started their new campaigns.

NO: because - Brexit, migrant crisis, rise of protectionism (read Trump), climate changes create a feeling of crisis that calls for international solutions. European countries are too small to tackle them by their own. On the same time the populist parties are shifting tactics towards EU. They are not longer trying to get out of the EU (Altinget, 2019) - Brexit proves it being economically and politically costly. But they want to reform the EU from the inside, so the anti EU parties alongside the pro EU parties would try to gather their support and encourage their supporters to vote. In that sense I think the second order the of EU elections mechanism would not play big role this time and perhaps in the future. That is why I'm 99% sure that it will not be the lowest voter turnout.

I think three kinds of results are possible for different reasons. There could be a 45% probability of a record low in the turnouts, driven by the growth of populist parties. Also, the second-order nature the EU elections have in comparison with national elections can be important: with the European migration crisis and the uncertain developments in the Brexit deal can drive people to a lower attention to communitarian issues. Another outcome is more probable, in my opinion. There could be a 50% probability that the voters' turnout will be not meaningfully decreased in comparison with the 42.61% of the 2014 elections. This can be explained through multiple factors. The very increase of populist parties in Europe does not necessarily imply a lower turnout in the European elections, it could also lead to a wider representation of these parties in the EU Parliament. Furthermore, as often European elections are used by electors to give their national leaders signs about their satisfaction/dissatisfaction with their internal politics, many voters can seize the oportunity to give a clear message. If this outcome will happen, there is a strong risk of misleading interpretations: the stable turnout - far from being a good sign - must not be explained with a revival of the European belonging feeling, but with the previous explanations. The reasons which explain the 45% probability of a lower turnout are also the ones which explain the reason why I give only a 5% probability to a higher torunout. I cannot exclude a surprise - a record Italian turnout to support the Lega in its migrations policies, a record UK's turnout deriving from an unsuccesfull Brexit process, etc - but I am not induced to thik that the historical decreasing pattern of participation will end in 2019. Sources: most of all the ones indicated in the forecast's question + Gaspare Nevola, Democrazia, Costituzione, Identità, 2006

While voter turn-out in the European elections have been on a downwards trend, there is reason to believe that this will not continue with the 2019 election. Firstly, in response to the low voter turnout in 2014, the EU initiated the ‘this time I am voting campaign’ to increase awareness about EU elections and mobilize voter participation all across Europe (http://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/elections-press-kit/2/this-time-i-m-voting) . Secondly, the EU has featured as a major talking point across different European countries in the light of events such as Brexit and border closings. This could mean an increased interest in the EU and its work, whether as a supporter or a skeptic, and thereby an increased interest for potential voters to participate in EU elections (https://www.euronews.com/2019/02/12/european-election-2019-this-time-will-be-different). Moreover, the EU elections will be held in conjunction with local and regional elections in both Ireland and Spain, which could secure, and potentially increase, and already above-average voter turnout in these two countries (http://www.europarl.europa.eu/about-parliament/en/in-the-past/previous-elections). The UK will most likely not be voting in the European election, even if they were to extend the notification of article 50 (https://www.ft.com/content/901f95fe-1a70-11e9-9e64-d150b3105d2). As the UK voter turnout has been on the lower side, the overall average voter turnout will be positively influenced by this absence. However, there is still a chance that despite these variables, the voter turnout will continue its downward trend, and I therefore assign a 15% probability of that happening.

What drives our answer here is the idea that in 2019, the European context will bring more people to the ballot boxes than in 2014. If I do not necessarily expect to see a substantially higher participation rate, I personally doubt that it can supplant the 42.61% of 2014.

85% of No Even though we are witnessing a slow decline in the participation rate since 1979, going from a rate of 61.99% to 42.61% in 2014, however since 2009, it seems to have been a stabilization when the decline was 42.97%,with a decrease of 0.36% in 2014. The recent events and the current European context will surely boost the participation rate. Indeed, the European Union is very questioned, but this state of affairs will not push towards abstention. On the contrary, eurosceptics through a protest vote will manifest this position very strongly. Eurosceptic partys take the vote more seriously than partys with a broader base. The Hungarian populists (turnout of 28.97% in Hungary) and Polish (turnout of 23.83% in Poland in 2014) will try to have a bigger place in the parliament and will therefore encourage their voters, always more numerous from day to day, to support them to overturn the pro-eu majority in the Parliament. Italians too will have a greater desire to express themselves with the advent of Salvini. The protest voting theory also shows that voters use peripheral polls to punish the holders of central power in the home country (Mair 2004).

The overall question remains: whether voter apathy will maintain a steady decline of voter turn-out since 1979 (continuity), or contemporary political forces have and will rally voter turn-out (contingencies). This current prediction leans slightly towards contingency.

Reasons against: • UK turnout in those elections has traditionally been lower than the average, which indicates that brexit would increase the overall voter turnout percentage, by the sheer fact of the UK lower turnout being removed from the overal calculations. (https://www.politico.eu/interactive/voters-turnout-in-the-european-elections/) • EU will likely see this election as fundamental in re-establishing itself after Brexit. It will likely start campaigning heavily. However currently seeing no sign for this yet. Reasons in favor: • Voter turnout for the European union has been in decline since 1984, with a record low in 2014 ((https://www.politico.eu/interactive/voters-turnout-in-the-european-elections/)) • Patterns of increased euro-skepticism, combined with brexit, show decline in belief of the EU, and why vote for something you don't believe in in the first place. (https://www.clingendael.org/pub/2017/monitor2017/a_crisis_of_confidence_in_the_european_union/) • Unclarity regarding the Brexit procedures likely increases the disbelief in the EU Overall: I think the purely statistical advantage of Brexit is outweighed by the increase of Euro-skepticism and will dampen the Voter turnout further. Only increased campaigning can offset this.
I expect static to slightly increased rate barring Britain. If Britain still part of EU when vote takes place their apathy would drive it lower.

The Brexit-EU debate and the influx of migrants in 2015 are examples of high level events and trends that have caused increasing interest in European politics. This makes it likely that both eurosceptic and pro-european voters will view this particular election as important and will want to cast their vote. The latest Eurobarometer survey supports this general trend and for instance shows increasing voter interest in EU policies and an increase in likelihood of wanting to vote (http://www.europarl.europa.eu/at-your-service/files/be-heard/eurobarometer/2018/eurobarometer-2018-democracy-on-the-move/report/en-one-year-before-2019-eurobarometer-report.pdf).
Dumb money likes 0-30%--taking the other side.

The voter turnout has declined with every European Parliament election, but the decline has flattened out in recent elections, and the difference in voter turnout between the previous two elections was very small, less than 1%. I can't speak for all European countries, but in Germany, voter turnout increased in all recent state and national elections, presumably due to the rise of the far right party which mobilised people who would not previously have voted, but on the other hand also people who would make sure to vote to counter the far right. I would argue that particularly in the more populous countries of Europe, politics have been very tumultous, or extreme, in the past few or couple of years, which means people in general are perhaps more aware and talking about politics than they would have a few years ago, and due to Brexit the same may be the case for EU politics. This may mean that more people have opinions on the EU and will bother to vote. So I doubt that voter turnout will be a record low, however, given an overall frustration with politics and/or the EU, feeling that the vote wouldn't matter, and lack of relatedness to the EU parliament, pariticularly in Eastern European countries, could still mean that a substantial number of people don't bother to vote.

Main factors taken into consideration: Trend driven voter turnout in major european countries decreasing (germany, france) -> higher probability, voter turnout last time slightly lower then the year before -> higher probability,

I start with 33% probability. PRO: Each subsequent election had lower turnout in since 1979. Turnout has been falling in many large countries in other elections as well (Italy), but not in all (Germany). AGAINST: If Brexit happens before the election, a large low-participation country will be out (35% turnout in 2014) - this could tip the scales. Spain will have European and local elections together, which would drive participation up in a large country (did any other major country have multiple elections in 2014?). Populist parties are on the rise and immigration a hot topic, possiblity increasing turnout in voter segments, which neglected European elections in the past. The trends suggest that the voter turnout is continuously decreasing. I think that the answer to this question can only really be determined once the participation status of the United Kingdom is determined. I believe that if they go through with exiting the EU, there will be a notable increase in voter turnout.

Brexit is likely to ensure that the EU is salient in the minds of European voters. It is likely to provoke an anti-UK and pro-EU backlash as well as an anti EU backlash among Eurosceptics. All of this will incite higher turnout.

While each election has had lower turnout than the last, the debate in Europe over populism vs the establishment is redrawing battle lines and I think that will encourage the partisans on both sides to turn out. Particularly considering the efforts of Macron and Salvini to organize their respective sides around these ideas instead of the existing dividing line in the European Parliament, which I think is over which kind of integrationist the parties are.

Voter turnover for Euro elections have stabilized over the last elections and were rising for many national elections in European countries. Moreover, Europe is a big topic for both, pro- and con Europeans, so that the chances are high that both groups try to activate voters more than usual.

The trend is the most powerful reason to expect this to occur and shouldn't be ignored. But, given the increasing controversy and possibility that the UK will have exited, it seems worth betting against.
